description:
This story takes place at the end of the 19th century in London. A famous dog detective, Sherlock Hound, was relaxing with his pipe... Dr. Watson is, of course, with Sherlock. The night is very foggy. From the light of a street gas lamp, one can only see for a few yards. From the distance, a coach comes dashing towards Baker Street and stops in front of Hound's flat. Someone violently knocks at the door. "Watson, something's afoot!!" Hound in his well-known deer stalker hat and Inverness cape, leaves his flat in his prototype Benz with Dr. Watson.

(Source: Crunchyroll)

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Anthropomorphism
tags.description: Contains non-human character(s) that have attributes or characteristics of a human being.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

title.native: 名探偵ホームズ 青い紅玉の巻/海底の財宝の巻
劇場版名探偵ホームズ　ミセス・ハドソン人質事件の巻／ドーバー海峡の大空中戦の巻

node.description:
__Residency:__ Tokorozawa City, Saitama Prefecture, Japan
__Graduated:__ Gakushuin University (Department of Economics)

__Introduction:__
Hayao Miyazaki is a Japanese animator, director, script/screenwriter, author, mangaka and co-founder of Studio Ghibli. He is the second of four brothers, and was born in the town of Akebono-cho, part of Tokyo's Bunkyou Ward. He is best known for his international fame as a masterful storyteller and as a maker of astonishing animated feature films, and he is widely regarded as one of the most accomplished filmmakers in the history of animation.

Miyazaki's works are characterized by the recurrence of themes such as humanity's relationship with nature and technology, the wholesomeness of natural and traditional patterns of living, the importance of art and craftsmanship, and the difficulty of maintaining a pacifist ethic in a violent world. The protagonists of his films are often strong girls or young women, and several of his films present morally ambiguous antagonists with redeeming qualities. Miyazaki's works have been highly praised and awarded; he was named a Person of Cultural Merit for outstanding cultural contributions in November 2012, and received the Academy Honorary Award for his impact on animation and cinema in November 2014, as well as having won two Oscars for Best Animated Feature, the only instances in which a non-English-language film has won the award. Miyazaki has frequently been cited as an inspiration for numerous animators, directors, and writers.

__Biography:__
Miyazaki expressed interest in manga and animation from an early age, which led to him eventually joining [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/Toei-Animation) in 1963. During his early years at Toei Animation he worked as an in-between artist and later collaborated with the director [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/Isao-Takahata). Some notable films Miyazaki contributed to at Toei include [Doggie March](https://anilist.co/anime/9228/Wan-Wan-Chuushingura/) and [Gulliver's Travels Beyond the Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/2833/Gullivers-Travels-Beyond-the-Moon/). He provided key animation in other films at Toei, such as the Puss in Boots and Animal Treasure Island, before moving to animation studio A-Pro in 1971, where he would co-direct the movie Lupin the Third Part I alongside Isao Takahata. After moving to Zuiyou Eizou (later dubbed [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/Nippon-Animation)) in 1973, Miyazaki worked as an animator on World Masterpiece Theater, and directed the television series [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/Future-Boy-Conan/). He joined [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/Telecom-Animation-Film)/Tokyo Movie Shinsa in 1979 to direct his first feature films, [The Castle of Cagliostro](https://anilist.co/anime/1430/Lupin-The-3rd-The-Castle-of-Cagliostro/) in 1979 and [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/Nausica-of-the-Valley-of-the-Wind/) in 1984, as well as the television series [Sherlock Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/1972/Sherlock-Hound/).

Miyazaki co-founded [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/Studio-Ghibli) in 1985. He would go on to direct numerous of films with Ghibli, including [Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/Castle-in-the-Sky/) (1986), [My Neighbor Totoro](https://anilist.co/anime/523/My-Neighbor-Totoro/) (1988), [Kiki's Delivery Service](https://anilist.co/anime/512/Kikis-Delivery-Service/) (1989), and [Porco Rosso](https://anilist.co/anime/416/Porco-Rosso/) (1992). The films they made were met with critical and commercial success in Japan. His film [Princess Mononoke](https://anilist.co/anime/164/Princess-Mononoke/) was the first animated film to ever win the Japan Academy Prize for Picture of the Year, and it briefly became the highest-grossing film in Japan following its release in 1997, and its distribution to the Western world greatly increased Studio Ghibli's popularity and influence outside of Japan. His 2001 film [Spirited Away](https://anilist.co/anime/199/Spirited-Away/) became the highest-grossing film in Japanese history, winning the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature at the 75th Academy Awards and is frequently ranked among the greatest films of the 2000s. Miyazaki's later films, [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/) (2004), [Ponyo](https://anilist.co/anime/2890/Ponyo/) (2008), and [The Wind Rises](https://anilist.co/anime/16662/The-Wind-Rises/) (2013) also enjoyed critical and commercial success.

Following the release of The Wind Rises, Miyazaki announced his retirement from feature films, though he returned again in 2016 to work on a new feature film, [The Boy and The Heron](https://anilist.co/anime/109979/The-Boy-and-the-Heron/) (2023). The film received critical acclaim, becoming the first non-English-language film to win the Golden Globe for Best Animated Feature Film, and the second non-English-language film, after Spirited Away, to win the Oscar for Best Animated Feature at the 96th Academy Awards. According to Studio Ghibli vice-president [Junichi Nishioka](https://anilist.co/staff/212700/Junichi-Nishioka) and long-time colleague, [Toshio Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101638/Toshio-Suzuki), Miyazaki is reportedly working on another feature film, contrary to rumours that The Boy and the Heron would be his last.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TkashiWatanabe)

Joined Top Craft as an animator while still attending university, switched his focus to directing in the late '80s.

Married to [Miyata Naomi](https://anilist.co/staff/220081/).

Yoshifumi Kondou was a Japanese animator who worked for [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) in his last years, and was most known for directing the film [Whisper of the Heart](https://anilist.co/anime/585/). He was expected to become one of the top directors at Studio Ghibli, alongside [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) and [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), and to become their eventual successor.

Kondou entered Niigata Prefectural Muramatsu High School in April, 1965, where he was a member of the art club. In the school, one of his seniors was the future manga artist [Kimio Yanagisawa](https://anilist.co/staff/100609/). In April, 1968, he moved to Tokyo after graduating from high school, where he entered Tokyo Design College's animation department. In October, 1968, he began working at [Shin-Ei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/247/), then A Production. There he took part in the production of shows like [Kyojin no Hoshi](https://anilist.co/anime/5834/) and [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/). In 1978, Kondou moved to [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/), where he worked on shows such as [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/) and [Anne of Green Gables](https://anilist.co/anime/283/), making his proper character designing debut in the latter.

In December 1980, Kondou moved to [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/), where he served as the character designer for [Sherlock Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/1972/). Kondou resigned from his position at Telecom in March of 1985, and was hospitalized from June through August for a type of pneumonia. He became a contract worker for Nippon Animation afterwards and moved to Studio Ghibli in January, 1987.

In 1995, he made his directorial debut with the renown Studio Ghibli film, Whisper of the Heart.

Kondou suddenly passed away from an aortic dissection on January 21, 1998, which according to doctors had been brought on by overwork. Kondou’s death is also believed to be the reason for Miyazaki’s initial announcement of retirement.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kaieisha_nizo_y) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/nizo_yamamoto/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/山本二三)

One of Japan’s leading scenic artists and art directors. Noted for his work as an art director on titles such as [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/), [Grave of the Fireflies](https://anilist.co/anime/578/), [Fantastic Children](https://anilist.co/anime/455/) and [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/).

He was also one fifth of [Princess Mononoke](https://anilist.co/anime/164/)'s art directors. In 1995, [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) went to the ancient forests of Yakushima, of Kyushu, an inspiration for the landscape of [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/), and the mountains of Shirakami-Sanchi in northern Honshu for location scouting along with the five art directors and other production staff.

On August 19, 2023, he died of stomach cancer at his home, aged 70.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%BE%BD%E7%94%B0%E5%81%A5%E5%A4%AA%E9%83%8E) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentar%C5%8D_Haneda)

Kentarou Haneda was a Japanese pianist, composer and arranger of popular anime and movies and video game music.

After graduating from the Toho Gakuen School of Music, he taught as a professor at the Tokyo College of Music. He was best known as composer of Wizardry music which was ported to NES and SNES console by Ascii at early 1990, The [Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) series, [Barefoot Gen](https://anilist.co/anime/1824/), Ys Symphony, Symphony Sorcerian and Genso Suikoden Ongaku-shu.

Haneda passed away from liver cancer on June 2, 2007.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Originating from [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/).

Sir Arthur Ignatius Conan Doyle was a Scottish physician and writer, most noted for his stories about the detective Sherlock Holmes, generally considered a milestone in the field of crime fiction, and for the adventures of Professor Challenger. He was a prolific writer whose other works include science fiction stories, plays, romances, poetry, non-fiction, historical novels and humours ('Exploits of Brigadier E.Gerard').

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/奥田誠治_(アニメーション演出家%29)

Seiji Okuda is a veteran anime director. He established Project Team Eikyuukikan, a collaboration of several animators, which was disbanded by him in October 2009. He continues to work freelance, mostly as storyboarder. He is also a member of the JAniCA.

_Note: Not to be confused with the producer [Seiji Okuda](https://anilist.co/staff/219343/)._

He was active in the 70s, 80s and the first half of 90s. In Transformers he wrote some episodes of The Headmasters, Super-God Masterforce, and Victory. Outside of Transformers, he wrote episodes for other giant mecha shows such as Mobile Suit Gundam, Daitarn 3, Xabungle and the second Tetsujin 28 show (aka New Gigantor), as well as non-mecha anime.

(Source: AniDB)

Following the release of The Wind Rises, Miyazaki announced his retirement from feature films, though he returned again in 2016 to work on a new feature film, [The Boy and The Heron](https://anilist.co/anime/109979/The-Boy-and-the-Heron/) (2023). The film received critical acclaim, becoming the first non-English-language film to win the Golden Globe for Best Animated Feature Film, and the second non-English-language film, after Spirited Away, to win the Oscar for Best Animated Feature at the 96th Academy Awards. According to Studio Ghibli vice-president [Junichi Nishioka](https://anilist.co/staff/212700/Junichi-Nishioka) and long-time colleague, [Toshio Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101638/Toshio-Suzuki), Miyazaki is reportedly working on another feature film, contrary to rumours that The Boy and the Heron would be his last.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/87896126)

While studying at Nihon University, Katabuchi participated in the writing team of [Sherlock Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/1972/), which's production also involved [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/). After graduating, he joined [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/).

In 1999, Katabuchi joined [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/), where he directed [Princess Arete](https://anilist.co/anime/1028/). The movie was released in 2001 and won Excellent Works of the Year in the Domestic Feature Film Category at Tokyo International Anime Fair in 2002. He joined [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) and worked for various animations including [Black Lagoon](https://anilist.co/anime/889/). In 2016, Katabuchi directed [In This Corner of the World](https://anilist.co/anime/15227/) which was released on November 12, 2016 in Japan, and planned to be released in fifteen countries including UK, France, Germany, Mexico and US.

Married to fellow director [Chie Uratani](https://anilist.co/staff/121177/).

He's a screenwriter who mainly deals with anime works.  During his training, he also studied under Kohan Kawauchi. In that connection, he also participates in anime and special effects works based on Kawauchi. In the 1980s, he was active in working on multiple works at the same time. There is a wide range of genres, from gag lines to serious ones. In recent years, he has also worked on original works such as graphic novels for men. Since the 2000s, he has been working on period drama novels.

He graduated from Hôsei University.
Affiliated with [OLM](https://anilist.co/studio/28/). Originally a director, but shifted his focus to composite work when animation went digital.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/瀬山武司) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takeshi_Seyama)
